regretList.regret: Can't say I really have regrets.  Yes, maybe I would have liked some things to be different but I realize that all of the experiences have helped mold me into who I am today, and all have been helpful to my personal growth. At the time I made those decisions to act or not act, I was doing the best I could with the information I had.  No regrets.
I regret I have not made more efforts to make real friendships with a diverse set of people.
My 30 year old daughter died suddenly and unexpectedly 2000 miles away. I so regret not being able to get there in time to hold her in my arms before she died.
I regret not standing up to a boy bullying my friend in junior high school.

I regret two things - I wish I had become a teacher much earlier in my career and I also regret that I didn't start teaching overseas much earlier too. Just finished 10 years abroad and now I've aged out of international teaching.
I regret the people I have hurt over my lifetime.
I regret that I didn't report my parents to CPS for abuse inflicted on me and my siblings, because I was more afraid of their threats and the unknown outcome.
That I didn’t have greater ambition.
I wish I would have lightened up a bit in my younger years. I was very serious and focused. I think I missed out on some fun.
We didn't call my husband's grandma to thank her for the gift for our new baby because we were broke and waited for the cheaper weekend rate.  She passed away on Friday.

1 A failed first marriage
2 not managed to connect my second wife well with my mother
Sometimes I don't think enough about the consequences that will resolve in doing/saying something especially with neighbors who are different in being and thinking but you have to live with...

(1) Not travelling to Poland to meet the Dad of my wife before he died. (Actually he just died this Monday)
(2) Not staying in the USA and bring the love of my life to the USA. Instead I returned to Europe. Never know how that would have turned out.

I felt that I need a new challenge in my professional career. In 2018 work sucked and I was feeling really depressed, however I did not dare to change job. My loan on the house, 2 kids and wife kept me from changing something. But things got even worse, I stayed on the job and 2019 became a complete desaster. I regret that I did not have the courage to change company in 2018 and then finally got pushed out in 2019.
Wrong Marriage
Dort judge in good or Bad, take it and enjoy it
Not being more understanding of my parents and their troubles when I was a child.
I regret being ruled by low-level fear. Fear of trying something new. Fear of failing. Fear of the unknown...
2nd marriage

One significant regret I have is my choosing the safe path in education and career where I could go to the best schools and get an easy job in my career.  Instead, I wish that I had pursued science and medicine, a path where I would have had to work much harder and possibly not have only success as I worked towards my one-time goal of being a medical doctor.

Not letting my husband parent more when our children were little.  I grew up in a dysfunctional home of divorced parents.  When I became a parent, I read everything I could get my hands on to be the best parent possible.  My husband did not and therefore, I thought I knew more.  Probably not, but I regret thinking I was the authority and not letting him take charge more equitably.  I wish I were less fussy and he could have been more hands-on with them.  He deferred to me, because if he disagreed, he felt he was once again, the bad guy.  He's a good guy and should have been 'allowed' to have his way.  I don't think his parenting style would have made a difference at all.  Our children are who they are; I don't think if I gave in a little more to my husbands opinion it would have made any difference.  Today, I just want them to know we did our best, and we love them more than life itself.  They are independent young people, moral, kind and hard working, aged 35 and 30.

I wrote five and a half novels, had a literary agent, failed to sell any of the books, and then simply stopped writing when what I loved about the previous ten years had been the immersion in story, anytime, anywhere not knowing what would emerge.I got serious about my "real" job with good success but miss my more playful life in fiction.
I regret that I did not ask my parents more questions about who they were and their life experiences while they were still alive.
I regret not initiating the separation and subsequent divorce from my husband in a way that would have kept things more amicable.

Not having the confidence to follow my heart or instincts. 
Trying to meet othere' expectations
That I didn't come out as a Gay Man.
I learned how to make other people happy. I never learned how to make myself happy

"Regret is like a bag of bricks. All you have to do is put it down." - Devil's Advocate. Its so easy to have wished for a different outcome to something - but you really don't know what would have happened. If I was rich and famous at 18 - maybe I become George Clooney - maybe I become Charlie Sheen. Regret is a waste of energy.

Not being more purposeful and assertive in my life...40 years of my life was spent married to a spouse with narcissistic tendencies, and I did't know it.  I waited all that time for support that would never show up.  Now, it's my turn to take care of me.
Not recognizing the seriousness of my father's dementia condition in its early stages.
I regret being such a troubled youth (in and out of trouble). Wasted 10 years of my life.
I regret not realizing what a growing field sports analytics was going to be, and missed the opportunity to get in on the ground floor of popular basketball analytics in the early 2000s.
I wish that I had accepted my children as they were, and who they were, instead of trying to change them to what I felt would be more successful in society.
Wish I did not stay with the same company for 15 years and changed jobs as soon as I was able to get my US citizenship.
I regret not having given my mother more verbal thanks and appreciation before she died prematurely.
I regret not taking up and playing a sport, such as golf. It would have been enjoyable and I could have made more friends.

I regret not standing up to my mother and my husband when they were each telling me bad things about the other.  They caused me to have a breakdown and become weak. This ruined my life from the time I was 30 until I was about 45.
I regret that I got my girlfriend pregnant when I was 22, then married her because it was the right thing to do.

I had my mom up to be with me the weekend before Mother's Day because my sister who I was not getting along with was supposed to have her the next weekend. She didn't show up. Her aides told me she was alone and I didn't go down to be with her. She died the next week.

After graduation from Cornell I did not understand the financial setbacks I would face going into hospitality operations. I went in and had a hard time getting out—- working an extreme amount of hours for little compensation which has set me back for years.
I wish I had thought more about a career that would have allowed me to be a mother and have something for myself after the kids were grown.

I had two professors in in college who had a major impact on my career in the field of education.After graduating from college,I choose not to go back to see them and tell them how valuable their guidance was to my career.Now,major regret on my part.
I regret not spending more time with my dad in the month before he died.
Not being vulnerable enough to say "I love you" to someone on their deathbed.
Not finishing doctoral degree and   Spending to much time on profession life during my children’s early years
I regret that I used to care more about being accepted by others (and would do things not in alignment with my heart) than I did about learning to love myself.

Not living in Europe 
Not living in New York City
I wish I had more compassion for my stepchildren when they were young.
not taking better care of myself when younger
not taking Bible as Literature class in college
I wish I'd majored in Visual Art in college.
Gossiping about others.
Going into debt for school instead of selling my stock to pay for it
I regret caring so much about what other people thought of me. I regret not being more true to myself because I thought I needed to act or be a certain way to be liked by others.
All the things that I left unsaid to loved ones
Didn’t play professional volleyball in Europe after college
I regret how hard I have been to myself. I wonder what my life would have been like if I had been more loving to me in how I see and talk to myself.
Paid more attention to the course of education

I wish I had chosen not my career  in engineering. I was too young to know what I liked so I just took up whatever my parents asked me to. I feel I could have been a very good psychotherapist or astrophysicist.
Have missed telling someone that I love them
Shutting down a nursery school I'd started and run for over six years.
Failed to QUIT PORN is the biggest regret of my life right now
I regret of not looking for global opportunity in my mid career
I regret not playing basketball enough when I had the chance to because of an accident.
I regret not choosing my college and undergraduate course more carefully
Unable to study Grad level in the US or UK some thirty years ago. I am from India.
I opted for Science in college despite having a strong liking for Humanities/Social Sciences
So far, that I haven't participated in public life to change forces that oppress women.
I regret putting so much importance on high school achievements that were set up merely for college.
I decided to help a talented person's project despite right away feeling poorly treated by the person. In retrospect, what seemed like the path of least resistance ended up being a terrible choice.
Not trying harder. Taking the wrong advice.
That I started smoking
That I did not change my plane ticket when my dad was dying.  He died the day before I was set to travel to see him.

Constantly looking forward to the next time I'd be home instead of fully enjoying my time at university. Looking back it feels as if I wasted so many opportunities to enjoy life before starting a job.
Not being a better father and husband

Allowing family dramas to consume my energies. I calculate that all those dramas stole my attention and energies. I could have spent it more productively. I am cognizant that I did allow it. I did not have a choice as a child, but now as an adult, I am reclaiming my time.
I regret that I supported other people's dream but abandoned my own. I regret that I did not marry or have children.
I regret not going to law school as a young woman.

I wish I had learned to study and then applied it to my school work over the entirety of my school career. It seems so small but I think it would have made things so much easier. BTW, I am a college grad and it's all fine, but what a wasted opportunity.
Spending too much time on things that were insignificant and not focusing on real passion.
Not taking a job in another city because of a person who I thought I was in one with at the time
test this thing.

Not quickly pursuing why Mike stopped calling me and finding out years later it was because my cousin lied to him so she would have a chance with him. He was the love of my life. I assumed he had figured out I just wasn’t good enough for him so I took it on the chin. He died a few years ago never knowing about the lies. If I had contacted him and sorted it out as soon as I knew we might have had several decades together. “Saddest words of tongue and pen—what might have been.”
I didn’t know the power or potential I had and how good I was until i was 75 and I wasted time.

I regret moving back to the United States when I was living overseas. I regret not being able to better understand work politics, as I think it would have helped me find and keep a better career path.

I don't really believe in regrets. Everything I've chosen has led me to where I am today. But I do wish I had acted with more self-compassion and self-love earlier and more consistently. You can't help others if you don't help yourself first.
I regret not learning the importance of selling products or ideas earlier in my life.

Opted for knee surgery, but the surgeon did much more than we agreed upon.  Wish I had been more patient and tried physical therapy instead because the surgery caused many problems from which I have never healed.

I regret that I didn't have more clarity about what I wanted to create in my life ie. the  importance of family and that I committed my love to one person which resulted in opportunity loss (no children) as our relationship ended after 21 years in what was devastating at the time.

Naively signing a joint tax return when my divorce lawyer warned me not to. The result was a nightmare that took 2 years to resolve. I signed it under duress, so I took great steps to forgive myself. For the first time in my life, I really fought for myself. Luckily it didn't turn out as bad as it could have. 
At the end of it all, I realized how much I never stood up for myself before. I allowed myself to be manipulated to do things and revolve my life completely around another person. When it all came to an end, I had to start over. And now, a number of years later, I am still rebuilding. This time stronger and on my own terms.
I didn't follow the milestones I planned.  Tbh, I didn't even try.
Not taking a job I wanted because my wife did not want to move.
That I did not follow my more likely successful career path when I began 40 years ago!
Acquiescing to pressure to get married.
I regret not being more ambitious about my career. Had I been more selfish I might have gone further.

Moving to Maryland for my ex-husbands job, leaving my family in Philadelphia. Left my big Italian family, taking 2 kids with me. I regret the birthdays and holidays away from my family, the traditions my children didn’t grow up with, not getting to know their cousins, not forging a relationship with my nieces and nephews. Taking the kids away from their grandparents. Always felt guilty about that.

I believe that with any given decision we do the best we can with the information that we have available and that the decision is shaped by the version of ourselves that we have access to.  I am the best version of myself that I have ever been and that would not be possible without having made each decision I made over the years.
I regret that I allowed headstrong passions drive my choices, which were ones that sometimes hurt people or placed my desires as the most important need to be filled.
That I never apologized to my parents about running away and getting married at a really young age.
I regret that I did not try harder to make a relationship work with a person I loved deeply.  He hurt me and I ended the relationship too readily.
I don’t regret anything I did. It was all a learning experience and shaped who I am today, and I know I was doing the best I could at the time.
I ended a great friendship with someone who, too often, argued against my my faith. I miss hanging out with him and I’ve thought about it almost everyday for the last four years. I miss you Mark.
I regret not pursuing a professional basketball career. I should have worked more on my post moves and made the league.
I regret not telling people more often that I loved them.
Moved to L.A. to pursue writing & acting, but lacked the confidence to actually attempt it. 16 years wasted!
Not moving back to Ireland and settling for less when returning back to work
I regret not being more adventurous, especially as it relates to activities and courses I selected in college.
Not spending more quality time with my Father
I made some bad investment decisions in the past. I was lured by the notion that I could build wealth quickly by trying to outsmart the market and exploring non-traditional ways to invest.

I wish that I had spent more time in the present with my young children.   We had 3 kids quickly and I spent too much team reminiscing about what happened to rushing to get to the next life milestone.   I want more of life’s little moments with my children back.
I should have been better prepared to leave my job than I was when they let me go.  This lack of preparation made my job search much harder and time-consuming.
I regret thinking that other people had everything figured out (turns out they were like me, just trying to make it through the day/week/month)
Not asking to be transferred out of a dysfunctional work environment.
Giving up my pets for a relationship. :(
Staying in a bad relationship for a long time.
I am bisexual and waited until I was 36 to accept that and act on it in any meaningful way.
I did not take advantage to work and live abroad after college and before marriage
Not a single regret in 78 years

My biggest regret is that I only started meditating 16 months ago and wish it were 45 years ago. It would have changed my life. I also regret not starting my current practice of gratitude 45 years ago.
I wish I had seen the warning signs as my husband fell deeper into depression. I would have taken action and saved our marriage.

Telling someone I loved that I did not love them, out of anger.
Leaving a good job where I couldn't handle the stress.
I wish I had learned a foreign language early in life.  I realize it's not too late now, but it would have been easier at 22 than at 72.
I regret not making more YouTube videos 10 years ago and starting my own online business.

Not taking part in relationships that could have been. 
Not being more open to entering relationships.
Not having had children.
Not taking more risks when I was younger

I regret repeating a racially derogatory phrase about Asian immigrants that a friend had said at a party a few days earlier.  I made the comment to some college classmates and felt sick about it when I was called out by a Canadian Asian classmate.

I listened to my parents about getting an education so that I could have a job vs doing what I love. I wanted to please them, and I thought they were speaking out of having tried and failed, not just from a place of fear (and of course, wanting safety for their child).
That I didn't get help earlier.
I wish i realized how important it is to do what you love when i was choosing my post secondary education. I wish there was an adult who knew what I know now that could have directed me a bit.
Having a fourth child. Should have stopped at 3

Rather than a regret, I have a wonder about what would have happened if I had done things differently, made what appear now as better choices...but I have no doubt that I did the best I could at the time with the understanding I had then. So I feel more self-compassion than regret and gratitude for all the many blessing I have experienced. Though I have made LOTS of "miss takes", I really spend very little time regretting the past today. Apart from being somewhat useless anyway, it does not contribute to my enjoyment of the all too fleeting present moment!
I did not leave my marriage when my gut told me to.
I've let fear of attention/embarrassment stop me from doing things at time that would have been positive.
Not taking advantage of opportunities that come up
Not having made peace with my mother before she died.
I regret not learning to speak in public. I am shy and I don't like talking in public
I didn't run for fun (5k and 10k)races when I was young and fit.
In 1988 I was to be a freshman at the University of Oklahoma school of architecture. I was so nervous and anxious I decided on the drive down to school in St. Louis not to go. I never went.

As a Viet Nam veteran, my biggest life regret is having experienced all that I experienced over there.  I'm 72 years old now, and I'm still carrying that with me.  I guess it's good that I don't forget my experiences but there are times that I just wish that I could let it all go away.
Not finishing - at least - my bachelor's degree before marriage and children. Even if I'd changed career field, it would have been prudent to complete the education in a timely manner.
I regret not discovering the hilarious and insightful book Enablon and Me http://posthill.to/1642933643 much sooner!
Befriending someone who was self-centered. Learned from the experience.

A couple was in the process of adopting two boys from another country asked what they might expect, given that the babies had been abandoned, were infants, and early care was unknown, I responded too curtly.  I said that the children may well have learning and behavior problems.  Who can predict the future?
Going into education as a career. I was a first generation college student and there were teachers in my family so I did what I had been exposed to.
I regret putting so much emphasis on my career when my kids were young. Spending extra time working to advance my salary instead of spending that time with them when they were young.
Those times I couldn't find a positive in a tough situation. I made too many "surface" decisions.
Not leaving a bad marriage sooner.
I did not listen to myself (I listened to others) and purchase an amazing piece of land when I had the chance to

Not leaving a terrible job sooner - instead I stuck around and let it eat away at my positivity and confidence.  I did eventually leave but it took a little while to rebuild that confidence.  I've made sure I have been more courageous to lead my career.
learning the importance of money too late in life, and making my teen years choices only on the basis of my dreams
That I was not able to find a way to keep a friend and do what I thought was right in a job.
Not having developed a disciplined financial savings habit at an early age
Cheating on my wife

That I didn't keep playing sport and music in my 20's and 30's. Now in my late 40's I get immense enjoyment out of these activities and can't for the life of me understand why I dropped them for a "career".
I regret not making more female friends in my younger years to provide mutual support through our lives

I didn't get to tell my father I loved him before he died.
I didn't get to attend my sister's funeral because of COVID-19 restrictions.
Missing my grandmother's funeral in Indonesia because I was studying in Singapore and the funeral date coincided with my university exam in Singapore
Getting married to my ex-spouse.
Not telling people I love that I loved them, before I couldn’t.
Not being bold enough to pursue my own path overtly - I got real lucky that I'm in a great place professionally & personally - dumb luck helped more than courage
It's not knowing how much some of my words and actions hurt the people I love and care for.
Not speaking my mind at the right time
I should have studied more when younger.
Married early instead of travelling more.
Putting work ahead of my own life
Not spending more time with my children when they were younger

Una vez fuí muy duro con mi hija pequeña (2 años), mis dificultades personales y mi inexperiencia como padre me hicieron recriminarle lo que había hecho hasta que lloró. No se lo merecía y fui cruel sin una razón lógica.

When a relationship experiences a setback, it is the responsibility of both to reach out to each other to speak, clarify, and heal the harm. I regret those occasions where I have not found my way back, and I still feel angry with those when it has been them not finding the way back.

In college, I had a relationship with a girl that became very dysfunctional - I neglected relationships, my schoolwork, etc. - and affected me in a significant way for many years after the relationship ended. I regret getting so deep into this relationship.
A lo hecho pecho
Not spending more time with my mother to support her when she had hepatitis B.
No real regrets...I believe I took the correct decisions in the context I lived then
I regret I did not sell my stocks when the market was at its peak.
not to have divorced sooner
Worrying too much about How I look and what others think of me that it hindered me from really living my full potential and doing and being what makes me most happy.
I regret many discussions with muy father, i was just a kid that needed to fight. Nowadays i would rather fight against many injustices of the world.
Not taking the appropriate actions on people at my former org
Not being able to see my Uncle on his deathbed and my Aunt in their senior home due to the pandemic.

At a service club breakfast I regret not following a mother to the other room when she removed her autistic child from our table. I didn’t know how to react to his behavior and just stared. She would have taught me so much and I would be a better person.
Not moving to the pacific northwest when I got out of college
Not pursuing a dream when I was young and had time to fail financially.

Not going to nursing school
Not going to Europe
Spending (way) too much time "getting over" an ex. I was young and literally thought it was my one shot at happiness, and was devastated when it ended.
I should have pushed to get a better math and science education than I have.

I regret my fear and impatience. Fear of meeting that skater boy at the lake to get to know him better as a shy teen. Impatient- not good at waiting so I missed meeting Bob Geldof and getting a peck on the cheek. Also a teen regret.
Not meeting my wife sooner.
I never travelled abroad in college.  As a result I waited to really engage in travel until adulthood.  I feel as though this provided me a diminished perspective on the worldz
I regret not taking more time with a loved one who died too soon.
I wish I hadn't changed my religion.  I still believe so much about and feel close to my old religion and don't feel comfortable in the new one.

Wow. So many significant regrets come to mind. You want just one...okay...here it is: Tolerating being mistreated - sexual abuse - and not standing up for myself. I was date raped at the age of 15 years old and I did not report it because I thought it was my fault. I was with a man 4 years older than me and he was giving me beer all night long. I passed out for a few seconds and it was too late.
Fighting with my father.
I wish that I had believed in myself when I was younger so that I would have applied myself in school and worked up to my potential.
I walked away from a Building Excellent Schools Fellowship and a job at KIPP St. Louis.  Both were dream jobs that I simply decided not to do.
Being a better step father
Have the courage to ask for help and to ask more questions.
Work as an educator abroad.
Failure to take chances because of fear of failure and ridicule. Letting my past experiences from my childhood take control my future.

regretList.regret: First marriage @ 21
Not finishing up my PhD degree.
Now that I'm 62 years old, I wish that I had done some research about how to create and implement kind and healthy emotional boundaries with others when I was much, much younger.
I wish I'd stuck with my physics major after my quantum physics class.
Behaving badly in my first marriage. Emotionally leaving before I physically did. Resolved to do better the second time  30 years ago, never have been tempted to stray this time around.
I regret not learning and practicing the skills to be a better friend

1) Working too much and not enough time with family and other areas of life improvement. 2) Came from a lower/middleclass family and worked hard to get into a top University. It was hard being surrounded by so many people of wealth (via cars, clothes, dorm accessorizing etc) and got swept away into parties and trying to be popular. My studies were pushed aside which is how I got in in the first place. Thus I regret not reflecting on my choices, not putting education first, and trying to be a people pleaser and subsequently a pushover and manipulated. Now I cannot support my family in the way I want to, yet am working hard to make up for it. However, once you fail in academia, the gates seem to be permanently shut. Education is important and should not be wasted. It should also be ubiquitously accessible.

I regret that I didn't take more chances when I was younger. I had opportunities to travel and try new things and fear kept me home. I was scared of things that as I look back now were not worth being afraid of - things like losing then current relationships, not knowing anyone. I don't regret where I've ended up and I know if things had different while I was growing up I probably would not be where I am now, but I also wonder if I had had those experiences where I would be.
Marrying my husband. I knew he was not the right one on my wedding day.
Married my first wife
I regret that I didn't join Toastmasters in my early 20's.  I avoided public speaking until I joined at age 59 and joining Toastmasters truly changed my life.
Adopting one of our foster kids. We had no idea what we were doing. Still don't, and it's massively affected every area of our lives, negatively.
Staying in a failed marriage for too many years.

I regret not spending more time with a dear friend who, overcome by depression, took his own life. I regret the foolish, callous things I said when I was in my 20s that hurt other people. I regret losing touch with my late graduate school mentor whose advice and outlook helped me so much.
One of my biggest regrets is that my influence being a "Big Sister" 20 years ago was not sufficient to prevent my Little Sister from staying in the cycle of poverty and early pregnancey.
Regretfully, I was unable to complete my education which prevented me from doing something meaningful with my life.
Wish I had taken a “gap” year after college instead of going straight to law school.
Regret not getting a professional college degree immediately following high school.
I regret not standing up for myself in a work related ambush.
Not taking advantage of entering a doctoral program when offered
Wish that I had been kinder and more thoughtful to people I loved.
Speaking without thinking, reacting emotionally
Not making my brother my best man

I try not to mire myself in regret. I try to remember life is a process and at every step I have struggled to do the best I could at the time under the circumstances about me.
If I could change a few things; I would have done a lot fewer drugs (marijuana) in high school. I pretty much quit after high school, but I think I damaged my brain, I certainly damaged my social development. Another result was, I did not listen to my parents as well as I should have. Always hard for a teen anyway!
I would say that college boyfriend was the biggest regret (however I am also keenly aware that everything "post-a-hole" was truly a blessing because of him.
I regret not managing my money better from a young age. I've been working since I was 15 and don't have nearly enough to show for it.
Not taking a chance due to fear of unknowns.
I greatly regret that I bullied someone in high school
Screwing up my job at Johnstown
That I had learned to trust Christ fully much earlier in life.
Eu me arrependo de não ter viajado mais.
My main regret is having worked 17 hours a day for 10 years.

Not finishing Tavistock certification
Not doing PhD

Mi mayor arrepentimiento fue no haberme separado antes de una persona manipuladora y abusiva. Desafortunadamente, cuando estamos involucrados en relaciones abusivas, no nos damos cuenta de lo dañinos que son para nuestra salud mental.
I regret being to shy in the beginning of my career and being risk-averse.
Not really living up to the love I used to get (and really still do) by my mother
I regret not coming back with him on that night. There was never an opportunity to do that again, and there never will be.
Not stayed in NY with my ex
I regret not maximizing my oportunities instead of just doing the average (i.e. not studying really really hard at College).

I was planning on building my dream house with my wife and three children. I told my parents to sell their house (which they lived in for 40 years) to come and live with us in our new bi-generational house. They were so happy, they choose their kitchen, bathroom bought new furniture. 2 years after i was divorced and had to sell the house. They are presently living in a small appartment. It breaks my heart every time i talk to them.

I regret a lack of perspective in how i viewed education and careers early on (until ~age 25).  I viewed my undergraduate education as a means to get a job instead of as a way to explore different fields to learn what  I like. Over the course of 7 years, the situation continued to eat at me until one Sunday evening when he finally answered "yes" to my question about whether they were sleeping together. It took another 6 years for him to finally agree to a divorce because he "didn't want to destroy the family." I regret it so much, even though others always reassure me, "it was an accident, you didn't do it on purpose" - but this sticks in my throat. I wished that I wasn't so stupid and reckless.
